On September 22, 2016 [[Yahoo]] reported that account information for up to 500 million user had been [[hack]]ed.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html?_r=0 | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "state sponsored."<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_yahoo-switch-330pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> It was believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, addresses, passwords, telephone numbers and possibly encrypted information including security questions.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Further the statement claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html?_r=0 | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far reaching consequences involving privacy including potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html?_r=0 | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> It was not immediately certain how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_yahoo-switch-330pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[The Real Deal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9?r=US&IR=T|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref>

500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It was believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, addresses, passwords, telephone numbers and possibly encrypted information including security questions.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Further the statement claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html?_r=0 | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html?_r=0 | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> 

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9?r=US&IR=T|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

{{current|date=September 2016}}

On September 22, 2016, [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] reported that account information for up to 500 million users had been [[Security hacker|hacked]] in late 2014.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> According to the [[BBC]], this is the largest technical breach reported to date.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==Events==
Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "[[state-sponsored data breach|state-sponsored]]"<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It's believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> Further the statement claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It's believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> Further the statement claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

column4: It's the hack that is important. The disclosure is secondary.

In late 2014 [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed on September 22, 2016.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> According to the [[BBC]], this is the largest technical breach reported to date.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==Events==
Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "state-sponsored"<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed on September 22, 2016.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> The [[data breach]] is possibly the largest in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==Events==
Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]"<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which bought Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==See also==
* [[List of data breaches]]

{{reflist|2}}

url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[MySpace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the [[U.S. District Court of San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had reportedly offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the [[U.S. District Court of San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." The other was filed in the [[U.S. District Court of San Jose]], labeling the company "grossly negligent" in dealing with and reporting the security breach.<ref name=Sued>http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/</ref>

The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] has confirmed that it is currently investigating the affair.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=Sued/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." The other was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], labeling the company "grossly negligent" in dealing with and reporting the security breach.<ref name=Sued>{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}</ref>

The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] has confirmed that it is currently investigating the affair.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 550 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed two years later on September 22, 2016.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> The [[data breach]] is possibly the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[Password (computing)|passwords]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==Events==
Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]"<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=BBC |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=Sued/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." The other was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], labeling the company "grossly negligent" in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo has a policy of declining to comment on ongoing litigation and chose not to make a public statement in response.<ref name=Sued>{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}</ref>

The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] has confirmed that it is currently investigating the affair.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/><ref name=Sued/>

==Attribution of responsibility==
U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." The other was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], labeling the company "grossly negligent" in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo has a policy of declining to comment on ongoing litigation and chose not to make a public statement in response.<ref name=Sued>{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}</ref>

The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] has confirmed that it is currently investigating the affair.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/>

In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 550 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed two years later on September 22, 2016.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> The [[data breach]] is possibly the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[Password (computing)|passwords]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 />

==Events==
Yahoo alleged in its statement that the act was "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]"<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts">{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> but did not name any country.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.<ref name="Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts">{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=faq>{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}}</ref> The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information about friends, family and more personal aspects of people's lives that could be culled from emails.<ref name="Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014"/> Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/><ref name=Sued/>

==Attribution of responsibility==
U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The firm has faced two lawsuits as a result. One was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], stating that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." The other was filed in the U.S. District Court of [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], labeling the company "grossly negligent" in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo has a policy of declining to comment on ongoing litigation and chose not to make a public statement in response.<ref name=Sued>{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}</ref>

the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails.<ref name=faq/>

As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.<ref name="Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts"/> Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]] and [[Myspace]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1=
Paul|last1=Szoldra}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016 /> Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties.<ref name=Sued/>

Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/><ref name=Sued/>

==Attribution of responsibility==
U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]].<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/>

==Legal and commercial responses==
The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.<ref name=Sued>{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}</ref>

The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] confirmed that it was investigating the affair.<ref name=BBC_23_Sept_2016/>

==See also==
* [[Hacking (computer security)]]
* [[List of data breaches]]

==References==
{{reflist|2}}

==External links==
* [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs]
