Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s worth less than $2000 on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=25 September 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]]. ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} and claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects – but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' at the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives concluded that it was linked to Russia because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}} Security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs Sean Sullivan declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy — such as the energy sector — and lately to undermine politicians while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Examples of [[state-sponsored data breach]]es targeting technology companies with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=25 September 2016}} of 18m people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]], and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state-sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[cybercriminal]] group or individual – particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo]] notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the world wide web, which makes it a good – and valid – target for nation-state intelligence collection". According to an interview by ''[[WIRED]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[Instant messaging|IM]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the hack was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some of the members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew didn't want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse—as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
==Legal and commercial responses== The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{citenews|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==Access to the data== As the online black market site [[TheRealDeal]] is under [[DDoS]] attack the status of the listing's sale is unknown. Other actors having access to this data include the United States' [[NSA]] which has access to Yahoo's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] as well as by other methods. Similarly to the breach the NSA and GCHQ have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain [[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect metadata and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}. ==See also== * [[Hacking (computer security)]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]
column4: /* Attribution of responsibility and motivation */ italics for titles

column2:
In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} The [[data breach]] is possibly the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[Password (computing)|passwords]]. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions & answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives that could be culled from mail-accounts whose password was cracked or any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account-data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails. [[Cybersecurity]] expert Per Thorsheim claims that there are "lots of people, millions of people, who don't understand they have a Yahoo account" such as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky.com|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]]{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|publisher=Sunday Express|accessdate=25 September 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=25 September 2016}} As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s worth less than $2000 on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=25 September 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. While Yahoo did not name any country some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects – but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state-sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[cybercriminal]] group or individual – particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo]] notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the world wide web, which makes it a good – and valid – target for nation-state intelligence collection". According to an interview by ''[[WIRED]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[Instant messaging|IM]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the hack was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now "Peace_of_mind" responds:

The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.

Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)

In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Here's why it wanted more.|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==See also== * [[Hacking (computer security)]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]

In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} The [[data breach]] is possibly the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[Password (computing)|passwords]]. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions & answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives that could be culled from mail-accounts whose password was cracked or any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account-data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails. [[Cybersecurity]] expert Per Thorsheim claims that there are "lots of people, millions of people, who don't understand they have a Yahoo account" such as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky.com|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]]{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|publisher=Sunday Express|accessdate=25 September 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=25 September 2016}} As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s worth less than $2000 on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=25 September 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]]. ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} and claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects – but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 September 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' at the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives concluded that it was linked to Russia because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}} Security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs Sean Sullivan declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy — such as the energy sector — and lately to undermine politicians while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Examples of [[state-sponsored data breach]]es targeting technology companies with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=25 September 2016}} of 18m people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]], and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state-sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[cybercriminal]] group or individual – particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo]] notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the world wide web, which makes it a good – and valid – target for nation-state intelligence collection". According to an interview by ''[[WIRED]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[Instant messaging|IM]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the hack was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some of the members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew didn't want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse—as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
==Legal and commercial responses== The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==Access to the data== As the online black market site [[TheRealDeal]] is under [[DDoS]] attack the status of the listing's sale is unknown. Other actors having access to this data include the United States' [[NSA]] which has access to Yahoo's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] as well as by other methods. Similarly to the breach the NSA and GCHQ have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain [[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect metadata and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==See also== * [[Hacking (computer security)]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]

==Legal and commercial responses== The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==Access to the data== As the online black market site [[TheRealDeal]] is under [[DDoS]] attack the status of the listing's sale is unknown. Other actors having access to this data include the United States' [[NSA]] which has access to Yahoo's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] as well as by other methods. Similarly to the breach the NSA and GCHQ have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain [[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect metadata and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==See also== * [[Hacking (computer security)]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]
column4: possibly the largest --> one of the largest

column2:
In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!|Yahoo Inc.]] user accounts. This information was disclosed two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | publisher=New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} The [[data breach]] is one of the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[Password (computing)|passwords]]. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} but the organization did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=23 September 2016 |accessdate=23 September 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=23 September 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions & answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives that could be culled from mail-accounts whose password was cracked or any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account-data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, reviewing their accounts for suspicious activity, being cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoiding clicks on links or download of attachments from suspicious emails. [[Cybersecurity]] expert Per Thorsheim claims that there are "lots of people, millions of people, who don't understand they have a Yahoo account" such as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky.com|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]]{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|publisher=Sunday Express|accessdate=25 September 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=25 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=25 September 2016}} As of 23 September 2016, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|publisher=WIRED|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|accessdate=22 September 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s worth less than $2000 on the [[dark web marketplace]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=22 September 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=25 September 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered [[United States Dollar|$]]4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident in the [[history of the Internet]]. ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | publisher=Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=22 September 2016}} and claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects – but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 September 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' at the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives concluded that it was linked to Russia because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=25 September 2016|publisher=The Wall Street Journal}} Security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs Sean Sullivan declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy — such as the energy sector — and lately to undermine politicians while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|publisher=Financial Times|accessdate=25 September 2016}} Examples of [[state-sponsored data breach]]es targeting technology companies with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=25 September 2016}} of 18m people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]], and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state-sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[cybercriminal]] group or individual – particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo]] notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the world wide web, which makes it a good – and valid – target for nation-state intelligence collection". According to an interview by ''[[WIRED]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[Instant messaging|IM]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the hack was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some of the members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew didn't want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse—as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
==Legal and commercial responses== The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], plaintiff contend that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN.com]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==Access to the data== As the online black market site [[TheRealDeal]] is under [[DDoS]] attack the status of the listing's sale is unknown. Other actors having access to this data include the United States' [[NSA]] which has access to Yahoo's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]] as well as by other methods. Similarly to the breach the NSA and GCHQ have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain [[Muscular (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect metadata and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==See also== * [[Hacking (computer security)]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]
