Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. At the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives were said to have concluded that it was linked to Russia, because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as its top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. [[Comodo Group]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection". ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal as of September 22, 2016, was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]], the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==See also== * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]
column4: /* Legal and commercial responses */ +info on letter by 6 senators

column2:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!]] user accounts. This breach was publicly disclosed by Yahoo two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | work=The New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} The [[data breach]] is one of the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[password]]s. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=September 23, 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts, including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions and answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy, potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives—including information pulled from any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, review their accounts for suspicious activity, be cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments from suspicious emails. [[Computer security]] experts point out that there may be millions of people, as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky plc|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]] who do not realize that they have a Yahoo! account.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|work=Sunday Express|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|work=WIRED|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s, (less than [[United States dollar|US$]]2000) on the [[darknet market]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 22, 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon Communications]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered $4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. CEO of the company, [[Marissa Mayer]], has known about the data breach since at least July 2016, but withheld the information from investors, regulators and acquirer Verizon until September.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/23/yahoo-ceo-mayer-knew-about-data-breach-in-july-report.html|title=Yahoo CEO Mayer knew about data breach in July: Report|first=Harriet|last=Taylor|date=September 23, 2016|publisher=CNBC}} Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident made public in the [[history of the Internet]]. Other actors having access to Yahoo's data and more include the United States' [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), which has access to the company's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], as well as by other methods. Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. At the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives were said to have concluded that it was linked to Russia, because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as its top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. [[Comodo Group]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection". ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]] {{as of|2016|September|22|df=US|lc=y}}, the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==See also== * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!]] user accounts. This breach was publicly disclosed by Yahoo two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | work=The New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} The [[data breach]] is one of the largest in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[password]]s. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=September 23, 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts, including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions and answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy, potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives—including information pulled from any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, review their accounts for suspicious activity, be cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments from suspicious emails. [[Computer security]] experts point out that there may be millions of people, as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky plc|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]] who do not realize that they have a Yahoo! account.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|work=Sunday Express|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|work=WIRED|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s, (less than [[United States dollar|US$]]2000) on the [[darknet market]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 22, 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon Communications]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered $4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. [[Marissa Mayer]], the CEO of [[Yahoo]], has known about the data breach since at least July 2016, but withheld the information from investors, regulators and acquirer Verizon until September.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/23/yahoo-ceo-mayer-knew-about-data-breach-in-july-report.html|title=Yahoo CEO Mayer knew about data breach in July: Report|first=Harriet|last=Taylor|date=September 23, 2016|publisher=CNBC}} Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident made public in the [[history of the Internet]]. Other actors having access to Yahoo's data and more include the United States' [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), which has access to the company's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], as well as by other methods. Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. At the time of the 2014 attack, Yahoo executives were said to have concluded that it was linked to Russia, because it was launched from computers in Russia.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as its top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. [[Comodo Group]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection". ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]] {{as of|2016|September|22|df=US|lc=y}}, the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. ==See also== * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Information security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Yahoo!|Data breach]]

Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach.
