And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]] (DDoS) {{as of|2016|September|22|df=US|lc=y}}, the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. Verizon Communications Inc. Chief Executive [[Lowell McAdam]] said he wasn't shocked by the hack - according to him "we all live in an internet world, it's not a question of if you're going to get hacked but when you are going to get hacked". He left the door open to possibly renegotiate the $4.83 billion price tag.{{cite web|title=Verizon CEO Says Evaluating Whether Yahoo Hack Had ‘Material Impact’|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/verizon-ceo-says-evaluating-whether-yahoo-hack-had-material-impact-1476136610|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}} Craig Silliman, Verizon's general counsel told reporters in Washington Verizon has "a reasonable basis to believe right now that the impact is material" and that they're "looking to Yahoo to demonstrate [...] the full impact". The company's reputation has suffered online in the last few months, according to an analysis by marketing firm Spredfast: about 90 percent of the Twitter comments about Yahoo were negative in October up from 68 percent in August, before news of the hack.{{cite web|title=Verizon Says Yahoo Hack Could Reopen $4.8 Billion Deal Talks|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/business/dealbook/verizon-says-yahoo-hack-could-reopen-4-8-billion-deal-talks.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=15 October 2016}} On October 28 European privacy regulators outlined concerns about a 2014 data breach as well as allegations that the company built a system that [[Yahoo!#Storing_personal information and tracking usage|scanned customers' incoming emails]] at the request of U.S. intelligence services in a letter to Yahoo.{{cite web|title=EU Issues Data-Protection Warning to WhatsApp, Yahoo|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/eu-issues-data-protection-warning-to-whatsapp-yahoo-1477647543|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 October 2016}} They asked Yahoo to communicate all aspects of the data breach to the EU authorities, to notify the affected users of the "adverse effects" and to cooperate with all "upcoming national data protection authorities' enquiries and/or investigations.{{cite web|last1=Fioretti|first1=Julia|title=EU data protection watchdogs warn WhatsApp, Yahoo on privacy|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-dataprotection-whatsapp-yahoo-idUSKCN12S0X5|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 October 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|Computer Security}} * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Database security]] * [[Information security]] * [[Internet security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] * [[Web literacy]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking of Yahoo!|Data breach]] [[Category:Email hacking]]
column4: /* Legal and commercial responses */ +info on October 28 European privacy regulators' letter to Yahoo!

column2:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!]] user accounts. This breach was publicly disclosed by Yahoo two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | work=The New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} The [[data breach]] is the largest discovered in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[password]]s. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=September 23, 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts, including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions and answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy, potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives—including information pulled from any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, review their accounts for suspicious activity, be cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments from suspicious emails. [[Computer security]] experts point out that there may be millions of people, as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky plc|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]] who do not realize that they have a Yahoo! account.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|work=Sunday Express|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|work=WIRED|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s, (less than [[United States dollar|US$]]2000) on the [[darknet market]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 22, 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon Communications]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered $4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. [[Marissa Mayer]], the CEO of [[Yahoo]], has known about the data breach since at least July 2016 but withheld the information from investors, regulators and acquirer Verizon until September.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/23/yahoo-ceo-mayer-knew-about-data-breach-in-july-report.html|title=Yahoo CEO Mayer knew about data breach in July: Report|first=Harriet|last=Taylor|date=September 23, 2016|publisher=CNBC}} In a Sepember 9 securities filing, Yahoo said it wasn’t aware of any "security breaches" or "loss, theft, unauthorized access or acquisition" of user data.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Hackers Were Criminals Rather Than State-Sponsored, Security Firm Says|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-hackers-were-criminals-rather-than-state-sponsored-security-firm-says-1475081065|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=In September, Yahoo told Verizon it hadn't been hacked — but executives may have known for months|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-deny-security-breaches-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=15 October 2016}} Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident made public in the [[history of the Internet]]. Other actors having access to Yahoo's data and more include the United States' [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), which has access to the company's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], as well as by other methods. Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. Yahoo in fall 2014 detected what it believed was a small breach "involving 30 to 40 accounts", carried out by hackers believed to be "working on behalf of the Russian government" - according to Yahoo executives because it was launched from computers in that country. Yahoo reported the incident to the FBI in late 2014 and notified affected users.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Sean Sullivan, security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo Group|Comodo]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection".
Arizona-based cybersecurity company [[InfoArmor]] issued a report{{cite web|title=InfoArmor: Yahoo Data Breach Investigation|url=https://www.infoarmor.com/infoarmor-yahoo-data-breach-investigation/|accessdate=15 October 2016}} whose conclusion challenged Yahoo's position that a nation-state actor orchestrated the heist after reviewing a small sample of compromised accounts. According to the report the breach was the work of an Eastern European criminal gang who later sold the entire hacked database to at least three clients, including one state-sponsored group and since early 2015 no longer offer to sell the full database, but are seeking "to extract something from the dump for significant amounts of money" with the prices varying based on the value of the target. It is hard to know who the ultimate mastermind of a hack might be as [[criminal hacker]]s sometimes provide information to government intelligence agencies or offer their services for hire. Andrew Komarov, the firm's chief intelligence officer said the hackers, dubbed [[Group E (hacker group)|Group E]], have a track record of selling stolen personal data on the dark web, have been previously linked to breaches at LinkedIn, Tumblr, and MySpace.{{cite web|title=Here's Who Hacked Yahoo, According to One Cybersecurity Firm|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/29/yahoo-hacked-by-eastern-european-gang-cybersecurity-firm-says/|publisher=Fortune|accessdate=15 October 2016}} The company appears to have access to portions of the Yahoo database. It successfully [[password cracking|decrypted the passwords]] for 8 of 10 Yahoo accounts provided by The Wall Street Journal within a day, and provided personal information associated with the accounts. According to the investigation, Group E was the source of some databases sold by the two hackers, named "Tessa88" and "Peace of Mind" which the hacker group "used [...] to broker that data out".{{cite web|last1=Szoldra|first1=Paul|title=A cybersecurity firm is telling two very different stories of the Yahoo hack to news organizations|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsored-actor-2016-9|accessdate=15 October 2016}} According to InfoArmor, "the Yahoo data leak as well as the other notable exposures, opens the door to significant opportunities for cyber-espionage and targeted attacks to occur" and may be the key in several targeted attacks against US Government personnel, which resulted after the disclosed contacts of the affected high-level officials of intelligence community happened in October 2015.{{cite web|last1=Womack|first1=Brian|title=Yahoo Hacked by Criminals, Not State Sponsor, Security Firm Says|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-28/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsor-security-firm-says|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=15 October 2016}} ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]] (DDoS) {{as of|2016|September|22|df=US|lc=y}}, the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} The breach prompted two lawsuits against Yahoo. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In the other lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. Verizon Communications Inc. Chief Executive [[Lowell McAdam]] said he wasn't shocked by the hack - according to him "we all live in an internet world, it's not a question of if you're going to get hacked but when you are going to get hacked". He left the door open to possibly renegotiate the $4.83 billion price tag.{{cite web|title=Verizon CEO Says Evaluating Whether Yahoo Hack Had ‘Material Impact’|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/verizon-ceo-says-evaluating-whether-yahoo-hack-had-material-impact-1476136610|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}} Craig Silliman, Verizon's general counsel told reporters in Washington Verizon has "a reasonable basis to believe right now that the impact is material" and that they're "looking to Yahoo to demonstrate [...] the full impact". The company's reputation has suffered online in the last few months, according to an analysis by marketing firm Spredfast: about 90 percent of the Twitter comments about Yahoo were negative in October up from 68 percent in August, before news of the hack.{{cite web|title=Verizon Says Yahoo Hack Could Reopen $4.8 Billion Deal Talks|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/business/dealbook/verizon-says-yahoo-hack-could-reopen-4-8-billion-deal-talks.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=15 October 2016}} On October 28 the European privacy regulators "Article 29 Working Party" outlined concerns about the 2014 data breach as well as allegations that the company built a system that [[Yahoo!#Storing_personal information and tracking usage|scanned customers' incoming emails]] at the request of U.S. intelligence services in a letter{{cite web|title=ARTICLE 29 Data Protection Working Party Letter To Yahoo!|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/article-29/documentation/other-document/files/2016/20161027__letter_of_the_chair_of_the_art_29_wp_yahoo_en.pdf|accessdate=2 November 2016}} to Yahoo.{{cite web|title=EU Issues Data-Protection Warning to WhatsApp, Yahoo|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/eu-issues-data-protection-warning-to-whatsapp-yahoo-1477647543|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 October 2016}} They asked Yahoo to communicate all aspects of the data breach to the EU authorities, to notify the affected users of the "adverse effects" and to cooperate with all "upcoming national data protection authorities' enquiries and/or investigations".{{cite web|last1=Fioretti|first1=Julia|title=EU data protection watchdogs warn WhatsApp, Yahoo on privacy|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-dataprotection-whatsapp-yahoo-idUSKCN12S0X5|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 October 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|Computer Security}} * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Database security]] * [[Information security]] * [[Internet security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] * [[Web literacy]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking of Yahoo!|Data breach]] [[Category:Email hacking]]
column4: /* Legal and commercial responses */ +actual letter, minor tweaks

column2:
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!]] user accounts. This breach was publicly disclosed by Yahoo two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | work=The New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} The [[data breach]] is the largest discovered in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[password]]s. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=September 23, 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts, including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions and answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy, potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives—including information pulled from any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, review their accounts for suspicious activity, be cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments from suspicious emails. [[Computer security]] experts point out that there may be millions of people, as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky plc|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]] who do not realize that they have a Yahoo! account.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|work=Sunday Express|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|work=WIRED|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s, (less than [[United States dollar|US$]]2000) on the [[darknet market]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 22, 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon Communications]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered $4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. [[Marissa Mayer]], the CEO of [[Yahoo]], has known about the data breach since at least July 2016 but withheld the information from investors, regulators and acquirer Verizon until September.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/23/yahoo-ceo-mayer-knew-about-data-breach-in-july-report.html|title=Yahoo CEO Mayer knew about data breach in July: Report|first=Harriet|last=Taylor|date=September 23, 2016|publisher=CNBC}} In a Sepember 9 securities filing, Yahoo said it wasn’t aware of any "security breaches" or "loss, theft, unauthorized access or acquisition" of user data.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Hackers Were Criminals Rather Than State-Sponsored, Security Firm Says|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-hackers-were-criminals-rather-than-state-sponsored-security-firm-says-1475081065|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=In September, Yahoo told Verizon it hadn't been hacked — but executives may have known for months|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-deny-security-breaches-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=15 October 2016}} On November 9th the company stated in a securities filing{{cite web|title=UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION - Yahoo! Inc.|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1011006/000119312516764376/d244526d10q.htm|accessdate=10 November 2016}} that Yahoo employees knew in 2014 that a state-sponsored hacker had broken into its network.{{cite web|title=Yahoo Employees Knew in 2014 About State-Sponsored Hacker Attack|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/10/technology/yahoo-employees-knew-in-2014-about-hacker-attack.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=10 November 2016}} The document suggests that the company did not understand the extent of the attack until a claim by a hacker in July to have obtained vast amounts of Yahoo user data led to an intensification of an internal review.{{cite web|title=Yahoo discovered hack leading to major data breach two years before it was disclosed|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/11/10/yahoo-discovered-hack-leading-to-major-data-breach-two-years-before-it-was-disclosed/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=10 November 2016}} The filing also said that the company is now investigating evidence that the hackers behind the 2014 breach found a way to access user accounts without their passwords via a [[HTTP cookie|cookie]]-based attack.{{cite web|title=Yahoo knew of 'state-backed' hack in 2014|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-37936219|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 November 2016}} Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident made public in the [[history of the Internet]]. Other actors having access to Yahoo's data and more include the United States' [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), which has access to the company's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], as well as by other methods. Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. Yahoo in fall 2014 detected what it believed was a small breach "involving 30 to 40 accounts", carried out by hackers believed to be "working on behalf of the Russian government" - according to Yahoo executives because it was launched from computers in that country. Yahoo reported the incident to the FBI in late 2014 and notified affected users.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Sean Sullivan, security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo Group|Comodo]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection".
Arizona-based cybersecurity company [[InfoArmor]] issued a report{{cite web|title=InfoArmor: Yahoo Data Breach Investigation|url=https://www.infoarmor.com/infoarmor-yahoo-data-breach-investigation/|accessdate=15 October 2016}} whose conclusion challenged Yahoo's position that a nation-state actor orchestrated the heist after reviewing a small sample of compromised accounts. According to the report the breach was the work of an Eastern European criminal gang who later sold the entire hacked database to at least three clients, including one state-sponsored group and since early 2015 no longer offer to sell the full database, but are seeking "to extract something from the dump for significant amounts of money" with the prices varying based on the value of the target. It is hard to know who the ultimate mastermind of a hack might be as [[criminal hacker]]s sometimes provide information to government intelligence agencies or offer their services for hire. Andrew Komarov, the firm's chief intelligence officer said the hackers, dubbed [[Group E (hacker group)|Group E]], have a track record of selling stolen personal data on the dark web, have been previously linked to breaches at LinkedIn, Tumblr, and MySpace.{{cite web|title=Here's Who Hacked Yahoo, According to One Cybersecurity Firm|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/29/yahoo-hacked-by-eastern-european-gang-cybersecurity-firm-says/|publisher=Fortune|accessdate=15 October 2016}} The company appears to have access to portions of the Yahoo database. It successfully [[password cracking|decrypted the passwords]] for 8 of 10 Yahoo accounts provided by The Wall Street Journal within a day, and provided personal information associated with the accounts. According to the investigation, Group E was the source of some databases sold by the two hackers, named "Tessa88" and "Peace of Mind" which the hacker group "used [...] to broker that data out".{{cite web|last1=Szoldra|first1=Paul|title=A cybersecurity firm is telling two very different stories of the Yahoo hack to news organizations|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsored-actor-2016-9|accessdate=15 October 2016}} According to InfoArmor, "the Yahoo data leak as well as the other notable exposures, opens the door to significant opportunities for cyber-espionage and targeted attacks to occur" and may be the key in several targeted attacks against US Government personnel, which resulted after the disclosed contacts of the affected high-level officials of intelligence community happened in October 2015.{{cite web|last1=Womack|first1=Brian|title=Yahoo Hacked by Criminals, Not State Sponsor, Security Firm Says|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-28/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsor-security-firm-says|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=15 October 2016}} ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets. As well, password reuse —as seen in recent headlines of account takeovers of high profile people. Many simply don’t care to use different passwords which allows you to compile lists of [[Netflix]], [[Paypal]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], etc. to sell in bulk. (50K/100K/etc)
As the online black market site TheRealDeal was under [[DDoS|distributed denial-of-service attack]] (DDoS) {{as of|2016|September|22|df=US|lc=y}}, the status of the listing was unknown. ==Legal and commercial responses== {{See also|Security breach notification laws}} On November 9th it was reported that 23 lawsuits related to the breach have been filed against Yahoo so far. In one lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California]] in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], the plaintiffs contend that the hack caused an "intrusion into personal financial matters." In another lawsuit, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California]] in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], the plaintiff contends that Yahoo acted with [[gross negligence]] in dealing with and reporting the security breach. Yahoo declined to comment on ongoing litigation.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/news/companies/yahoo-sued-data-breach/|accessdate=September 25, 2016|publisher=[[CNN#Online|CNN]]|date=September 23, 2016|last=Larson|first=Selena|title=Yahoo facing lawsuits in the wake of massive data breach}}
In a letter to Yahoo CEO [[Marissa Mayer]], six democratic senators ([[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Patrick Leahy]], [[Al Franken]], [[Richard Blumenthal]], [[Ron Wyden]] and [[Edward Markey]]) demand answers on when Yahoo discovered the breach, and why it took so long to disclose it to the public, calling the time lag between the security breach and its disclosure 'unacceptable'.{{cite web|title=Letter to Marissa Mayer signed by 6 senators|url=https://www.leahy.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/9-27-16%20Yahoo%20Breach%20Letter.pdf|website=leahy.senate.gov|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Dennis|title=Senators Demand Answers of Mayer on Yahoo Data Breach|url=https://www.onthewire.io/senators-demand-answers-of-mayer-on-yahoo-data-breach/|publisher=OnTheWire|accessdate=30 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Kuchler|first1=Hannah|title=US senators demand answers from Yahoo|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/36fd9132-84e1-11e6-a29c-6e7d9515ad15.html|publisher=The Financial Times|accessdate=30 September 2016}} The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) confirmed that it was investigating the affair. Verizon Communications Inc. Chief Executive [[Lowell McAdam]] said he wasn't shocked by the hack - according to him "we all live in an internet world, it's not a question of if you're going to get hacked but when you are going to get hacked". He left the door open to possibly renegotiate the $4.83 billion price tag.{{cite web|title=Verizon CEO Says Evaluating Whether Yahoo Hack Had ‘Material Impact’|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/verizon-ceo-says-evaluating-whether-yahoo-hack-had-material-impact-1476136610|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}} Craig Silliman, Verizon's general counsel told reporters in Washington Verizon has "a reasonable basis to believe right now that the impact is material" and that they're "looking to Yahoo to demonstrate [...] the full impact". The company's reputation has suffered online in the last few months, according to an analysis by marketing firm Spredfast: about 90 percent of the Twitter comments about Yahoo were negative in October up from 68 percent in August, before news of the hack.{{cite web|title=Verizon Says Yahoo Hack Could Reopen $4.8 Billion Deal Talks|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/business/dealbook/verizon-says-yahoo-hack-could-reopen-4-8-billion-deal-talks.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=15 October 2016}} On October 28 the European privacy regulators "Article 29 Working Party" outlined concerns about the 2014 data breach as well as allegations that the company built a system that [[Yahoo!#Storing_personal information and tracking usage|scanned customers' incoming emails]] at the request of U.S. intelligence services in a letter{{cite web|title=ARTICLE 29 Data Protection Working Party Letter To Yahoo!|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/article-29/documentation/other-document/files/2016/20161027__letter_of_the_chair_of_the_art_29_wp_yahoo_en.pdf|accessdate=2 November 2016}} to Yahoo.{{cite web|title=EU Issues Data-Protection Warning to WhatsApp, Yahoo|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/eu-issues-data-protection-warning-to-whatsapp-yahoo-1477647543|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=29 October 2016}} They asked Yahoo to communicate all aspects of the data breach to the EU authorities, to notify the affected users of the "adverse effects" and to cooperate with all "upcoming national data protection authorities' enquiries and/or investigations".{{cite web|last1=Fioretti|first1=Julia|title=EU data protection watchdogs warn WhatsApp, Yahoo on privacy|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-dataprotection-whatsapp-yahoo-idUSKCN12S0X5|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=29 October 2016}} ==See also== {{Portal|Computer Security}} * [[2012 Yahoo! Voices hack]] * [[Database security]] * [[Information security]] * [[Internet security]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Multi-factor authentication]] * [[Security hacker]] * [[Web literacy]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html Yahoo's Account Security Issue FAQs] {{Hacking in the 2010s}} {{Yahoo! Inc.}} [[Category:2014 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Data breaches in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking in the 2010s]] [[Category:Identity theft incidents]] [[Category:Internet privacy]] [[Category:September 2016 events in the United States]] [[Category:Hacking of Yahoo!|Data breach]] [[Category:Email hacking]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2016}} In late 2014, [[Security hacker|hackers]] stole information associated with at least 500 million [[Yahoo!]] user accounts. This breach was publicly disclosed by Yahoo two years later on September 22, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-hackers.html | title=Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Perlroth | work=The New York Times | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} The [[data breach]] is the largest discovered in the [[history of the Internet]]. Specific details of material taken include names, email addresses, telephone numbers, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers, dates of birth, and [[Encryption|encrypted]] [[password]]s. ==Events== Yahoo alleged in its statement that the breach was carried out by "[[Cyberwarfare|state-sponsored]]" hackers,{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts |first1=Hayley |last1=Tsukayama |first2=Craig |last2=Timberg |first3=Brian |last3=Fung | newspaper=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} but did not name any country.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-37447016 |title=Yahoo 'state' hackers stole data from 500 million users |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 23, 2016}} It is believed that the hack compromised personal data from the accounts including names, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, [[Cryptographic hash function#Password verification|hashed]] passwords (the majority with [[bcrypt]]) and, in some cases, encrypted or unencrypted security questions and answers.{{cite web | url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/your-yahoo-account-was-probably-hacked-company-set-confirm-massive-n652586 | title=Yahoo Says 'State-Sponsored Actor' Hacked 500M Accounts |first=Alyssa |last=Newcomb | publisher=NBC News | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|title=Account Security Issue FAQs|url=https://help.yahoo.com/kb/account/SLN27925.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=September 23, 2016}} The statement also claimed that the hacker was no longer in Yahoo's system and that the company was fully cooperating with law enforcement. Users were advised to be wary of unusual activity in their accounts, including suspicious emails. The information gained in the breach, especially the security questions and answers, could help hackers break into victims' other online accounts.{{cite web|title=Yahoo says ‘state-sponsored’ hack stole personal data from 500m accounts|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/technology/yahoo-says-state-sponsored-hack-stole-personal-data-from-500m-accounts|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Security experts cautioned that the incident could have far-reaching consequences involving privacy, potentially including finance and banking as well as personal information of people's lives—including information pulled from any other accounts that can be hacked with the gained account data. Yahoo recommends its users to change their password and security questions and answers for their Yahoo account as well any other accounts on which the same or similar credentials were used, review their accounts for suspicious activity, be cautious of any unsolicited communications that ask for personal information and avoid clicking on links or downloading attachments from suspicious emails. [[Computer security]] experts point out that there may be millions of people, as users of [[Flickr]], [[Sky plc|Sky]] and [[BT Group|BT]] who do not realize that they have a Yahoo! account.{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=If you're a Sky or BT customer – you need to reset your password NOW after Yahoo hack|url=https://www.express.co.uk/life-style/science-technology/713836/Sky-BT-Account-Email-Reset-Passwords-Yahoo-Hack|work=Sunday Express|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} or Yahoo users who stopped using their accounts years earlier.{{cite web|last1=Weise|first1=Elizabeth|title=Are you a Yahoo user? Do this right now|url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/news/2016/09/22/yahoo-breach-500-million-what-to-do/90849498/|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Isidore|first1=Chris|title=You could have a Yahoo account without even knowing it|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/23/technology/yahoo-account-hack/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Joseph|first1=Rebecca|title=Here’s what you need to know about the Yahoo hack|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2959197/heres-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-yahoo-hack/|publisher=GlobalNews|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Griffin|first1=Andrew|title=Yahoo hack: Hundreds of millions of people probably don’t know they are part of the world’s biggest data breach|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/yahoo-hack-flickr-account-how-to-know-what-to-do-have-i-been-hacked-data-breach-a7324701.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} {{As of|2016|September|26|df=US}}, it is unknown how long the company had been aware of the breach. Yahoo's confirmation of the [[data breach]] came almost two months after the company said it was investigating claims that a hacker, called "Peace_of_mind" or "Peace", who previously sold data taken from [[LinkedIn]], [[Twitter]] and [[Myspace]],{{cite web|last1=Greenberg|first1=Andy|title=An Interview With the Hacker Probably Selling Your Password Right Now|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/interview-hacker-probably-selling-password/|work=WIRED|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=The Administrator of the Dark Web's Infamous Hacking Market Has Vanished|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_au/read/the-administrator-of-the-dark-webs-infamous-hacking-market-the-real-deal-has-vanished|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 22, 2016}} was offering stolen user account details from 200 million Yahoo accounts for 3 [[bitcoin]]s, (less than [[United States dollar|US$]]2000) on the [[darknet market]], "[[TheRealDeal]]".{{cite web|title=The dark web marketplace where you can buy 200 million Yahoo accounts is under cyberattack|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/real-deal-market-ddos-2016-9|work=Business Insider|accessdate=September 22, 2016|first1= Paul|last1=Szoldra}}{{cite web|last1=Brian|first1=Womack|title=Yahoo Says at Least 500 Million Accounts Breached in Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-22/yahoo-says-at-least-500-million-accounts-breached-in-hack-attack|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=September 22, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Cox|first1=Joseph|title=Yahoo 'Aware' Hacker Is Advertising 200 Million Supposed Accounts on Dark Web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/yahoo-supposed-data-breach-200-million-credentials-dark-web|publisher=Vice Motherboard|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} A spokesperson for [[Verizon Communications]], which agreed to buy Yahoo! in July 2016, stated that Verizon had only become aware of the breach within the past two days. Verizon had offered $4.83 billion in July 2016 for Yahoo's core properties. [[Marissa Mayer]], the CEO of [[Yahoo]], has known about the data breach since at least July 2016 but withheld the information from investors, regulators and acquirer Verizon until September.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/23/yahoo-ceo-mayer-knew-about-data-breach-in-july-report.html|title=Yahoo CEO Mayer knew about data breach in July: Report|first=Harriet|last=Taylor|date=September 23, 2016|publisher=CNBC}} In a September 9 securities filing, Yahoo said it wasn’t aware of any "security breaches" or "loss, theft, unauthorized access or acquisition" of user data.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Hackers Were Criminals Rather Than State-Sponsored, Security Firm Says|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-hackers-were-criminals-rather-than-state-sponsored-security-firm-says-1475081065|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=15 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=In September, Yahoo told Verizon it hadn't been hacked — but executives may have known for months|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-deny-security-breaches-2016-9|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=15 October 2016}} On November 9th the company stated in a securities filing{{cite web|title=UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION - Yahoo! Inc.|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1011006/000119312516764376/d244526d10q.htm|accessdate=10 November 2016}} that Yahoo employees knew in 2014 that a state-sponsored hacker had broken into its network.{{cite web|title=Yahoo Employees Knew in 2014 About State-Sponsored Hacker Attack|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/10/technology/yahoo-employees-knew-in-2014-about-hacker-attack.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=10 November 2016}} The document suggests that the company did not understand the extent of the attack until a claim by a hacker in July to have obtained vast amounts of Yahoo user data led to an intensification of an internal review.{{cite web|title=Yahoo discovered hack leading to major data breach two years before it was disclosed|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/11/10/yahoo-discovered-hack-leading-to-major-data-breach-two-years-before-it-was-disclosed/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=10 November 2016}} The filing also said that the company is now investigating evidence that the hackers behind the 2014 breach found a way to access user accounts without their passwords via a [[HTTP cookie|cookie]]-based attack.{{cite web|title=Yahoo knew of 'state-backed' hack in 2014|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-37936219|publisher=BBC|accessdate=10 November 2016}} Multiple experts that have looked into the issue believe that the security breach was the largest such incident made public in the [[history of the Internet]]. Other actors having access to Yahoo's data and more include the United States' [[National Security Agency]] (NSA), which has access to the company's data via the surveillance program [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], as well as by other methods. Similar to the breach, the NSA and [[Government Communications Headquarters|GCHQ]] have secretly broken into the main communications links that connect Yahoo and [[Google]] [[data center]]s around the world in Britain's [[MUSCULAR (surveillance program)|MUSCULAR]] program and thereby gained the ability to collect [[metadata]] and content at will from hundreds of millions of user accounts.{{cite news|title=NSA infiltrates links to Yahoo, Google data centers worldwide, Snowden documents say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-infiltrates-links-to-yahoo-google-data-centers-worldwide-snowden-documents-say/2013/10/30/e51d661e-4166-11e3-8b74-d89d714ca4dd_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA is infiltrating private networks|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/national/the-nsa-is-hacking-private-networks/542/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Todd Lindeman |author3=Ashkan Soltani }}{{cite news|title=How the NSA's MUSCULAR program collects too much data from Yahoo and Google|url=http://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/world/how-the-nsas-muscular-program-collects-too-much-data-from-yahoo-and-google/543/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013|author1=Barton Gellman |author2=Matt DeLong }}{{cite news|last=Peterson|first=Andrea|title=PRISM already gave the NSA access to tech giants. Here's why it wanted more.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/30/prism-already-gave-the-nsa-access-to-tech-giants-heres-why-it-wanted-more/|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}}{{cite news|title=NSA statement on Washington Post report on infiltration of Google, Yahoo data center links|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-statement-on-washington-post-report-on-infiltration-of-google-yahoo-data-center-links/2013/10/30/5c135254-41b4-11e3-a624-41d661b0bb78_story.html|accessdate=October 31, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 2013}} ==Attribution of responsibility and motivation== According to Yahoo, the breach was carried out by a "state-sponsored actor"{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/09/22/report-yahoo-to-confirm-data-breach-affecting-hundreds-of-millions-of-accounts/ | title=Yahoo confirms data breach affecting at least 500 million accounts | work=The Washington Post | date=September 22, 2016 | accessdate=September 22, 2016}} and the organization claims that such "intrusions and thefts by state-sponsored actors have become increasingly common across the technology industry". While Yahoo did not name any country, some suspect China or Russia to be behind the hack.{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=China and Russia lead list of Yahoo hack suspects — but some doubt theory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/23/yahoo-hack-suspects-china-russia|work=The Guardian|accessdate=September 25, 2016}}{{cite web|title=U.S. Suspects Hackers in China Breached About 4 Million People’s Records, Officials Say|url=http://www.wsj.com/article_email/u-s-suspects-hackers-in-china-behind-government-data-breach-sources-say-1433451888-lMyQjAxMTE1NjA2NDYwMzQ2Wj|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} U.S. intelligence officials, who declined to give their names to the media, highlighted similarities between the attack and previous breaches linked to the [[Government of Russia|Russian government]]. Yahoo in fall 2014 detected what it believed was a small breach "involving 30 to 40 accounts", carried out by hackers believed to be "working on behalf of the Russian government" - according to Yahoo executives because it was launched from computers in that country. Yahoo reported the incident to the FBI in late 2014 and notified affected users.{{cite web|last1=McMillan|first1=Robert|title=Yahoo Executives Detected a Hack Tied to Russia in 2014|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/yahoo-executives-detected-a-hack-tied-to-russia-in-2014-1474666865|accessdate=September 25, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Sean Sullivan, security adviser at cyber security firm [[F-Secure]] Labs declares China as his top suspect and notes that "there have been no past cases of a service provider like Yahoo being targeted [by Russia]" whose hackers tend to perpetrate targeted attacks, either in areas important for their economy, such as the energy sector, and lately to undermine politicians, while "China likes to vacuum up all kinds of information" and "has a voracious appetite for personal information".{{cite web|last1=Murgia|first1=Madhumita|title=Cyber experts look to usual suspects in Yahoo hack|url=https://www.ft.com/content/0e3aecaa-81b1-11e6-bc52-0c7211ef3198|work=Financial Times|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} Examples of state-sponsored data breaches with China in suspicion are [[Office of Personnel Management data breach|the massive data breach]]{{cite web|last1=Nakashima|first1=Ellen|title=National Security Chinese breach data of 4 million federal workers|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/chinese-hackers-breach-federal-governments-personnel-office/2015/06/04/889c0e52-0af7-11e5-95fd-d580f1c5d44e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 25, 2016}} of 18 million people from the [[United States Office of Personnel Management]] and the attacks on Google in 2010, dubbed [[Operation Aurora]]. Others have expressed doubt of Yahoo's claim of the attack being state sponsored, as it would be less embarrassing for Yahoo to attribute an attack to a nation state, which typically have the most sophisticated hacking capabilities, than to attribute it to a [[Cybercrime|cybercriminal]] group or individual—particularly as Yahoo is in the middle of being acquired by Verizon. Senior research scientist Kenneth Geers from [[Comodo Group|Comodo]], however, notes that "Yahoo is a strategic player on the World Wide Web, which makes it a good—and valid—target for nation-state intelligence collection".
Arizona-based cybersecurity company [[InfoArmor]] issued a report{{cite web|title=InfoArmor: Yahoo Data Breach Investigation|url=https://www.infoarmor.com/infoarmor-yahoo-data-breach-investigation/|accessdate=15 October 2016}} whose conclusion challenged Yahoo's position that a nation-state actor orchestrated the heist after reviewing a small sample of compromised accounts. According to the report the breach was the work of an Eastern European criminal gang who later sold the entire hacked database to at least three clients, including one state-sponsored group and since early 2015 no longer offer to sell the full database, but are seeking "to extract something from the dump for significant amounts of money" with the prices varying based on the value of the target. It is hard to know who the ultimate mastermind of a hack might be as [[criminal hacker]]s sometimes provide information to government intelligence agencies or offer their services for hire. Andrew Komarov, the firm's chief intelligence officer said the hackers, dubbed [[Group E (hacker group)|Group E]], have a track record of selling stolen personal data on the dark web, have been previously linked to breaches at LinkedIn, Tumblr, and MySpace.{{cite web|title=Here's Who Hacked Yahoo, According to One Cybersecurity Firm|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/29/yahoo-hacked-by-eastern-european-gang-cybersecurity-firm-says/|publisher=Fortune|accessdate=15 October 2016}} The company appears to have access to portions of the Yahoo database. It successfully [[password cracking|decrypted the passwords]] for 8 of 10 Yahoo accounts provided by The Wall Street Journal within a day, and provided personal information associated with the accounts. According to the investigation, Group E was the source of some databases sold by the two hackers, named "Tessa88" and "Peace of Mind" which the hacker group "used [...] to broker that data out".{{cite web|last1=Szoldra|first1=Paul|title=A cybersecurity firm is telling two very different stories of the Yahoo hack to news organizations|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsored-actor-2016-9|accessdate=15 October 2016}} According to InfoArmor, "the Yahoo data leak as well as the other notable exposures, opens the door to significant opportunities for cyber-espionage and targeted attacks to occur" and may be the key in several targeted attacks against US Government personnel, which resulted after the disclosed contacts of the affected high-level officials of intelligence community happened in October 2015.{{cite web|last1=Womack|first1=Brian|title=Yahoo Hacked by Criminals, Not State Sponsor, Security Firm Says|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-28/yahoo-hacked-by-criminals-not-state-sponsor-security-firm-says|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=15 October 2016}} ===2012 hack=== According to an interview by ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' via [[Secure instant messaging|encrypted]], anonymous [[instant messaging]] with the person selling the accounts on the [[dark web]], "Peace_of_mind", the earlier hack in 2012 was done by a "'team' of Russians". On the question of how he came to possess this data and is only selling it now, "Peace_of_mind" responds:
Well, these breaches were shared between the team and used for our own purposes. During this time, some members started selling to other people. The people who we sold to [were] selective, not random or in public forums and such, but people who would use [the data] for their own purposes and not resell or trade. Although [after] long enough, certain individuals obtained the data and started to sell [it] in bulk ($100/100k accounts, etc.) in the public. After noticing this, I decided for myself to start making a little extra cash to start selling publicly, as well.
And to why the crew did not want to sell the whole collection earlier:
It is not of value if data is made public. We had our own use for it and other buyers did as well. In addition, buyers expect this type of data to remain private for as long as possible. There are many [databases] not made public for that reason and [in] use for many years to come.
And to the question of how he was able to make more by selling the data privately:
Well, [the] main use is for [[spamming]]. There is a lot of money to be made there, as [well as] in selling to private buyers looking for specific targets.
